t: John 10
The Good Shepherd and His Sheep

“Very*rp truly*r I*r tell*r you*r Pharisees,*r anyone*r who*r does*r not*r enter*r the*r sheep*r pen*r by*r the*r gate,*r but*r climbs*r in*r by*r some*r other*r way,*r is*r a*r thief*r and*r a*r robber.*r
The*r one*r who*r enters*r by*r the*r gate*r is*r the*r shepherd*r of*r the*r sheep.*r
The*r gatekeeper*r opens*r the*r gate*r for*r him,*r and*r the*r sheep*r listen*r to*r his*r voice.*r He*r calls*r his*r own*r sheep*r by*r name*r and*r leads*r them*r out.*r
When*r he*r has*r brought*r out*r all*r his*r own,*r he*r goes*r on*r ahead*r of*r them,*r and*r his*r sheep*r follow*r him*r because*r they*r know*r his*r voice.*r
But*r they*r will*r never*r follow*r a*r stranger;*r in*r fact,*r they*r will*r run*r away*r from*r him*r because*r they*r do*r not*r recognize*r a*r stranger’s*r voice.”*r
Jesus used this figure of speech, but the Pharisees did not understand what he was telling them.
Therefore*p Jesus said again, “Very*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r I*r am*r the*r gate*r for*r the*r sheep.*r
All*r who*r have*r come*r before*r me*r are*r thieves*r and*r robbers,*r but*r the*r sheep*r have*r not*r listened*r to*r them.*r
I*r am*r the*r gate;*r whoever*r enters*r through*r me*r will*r be*r saved.*r They*r will*r come*r in*r and*r go*r out,*r and*r find*r pasture.*r
The*r thief*r comes*r only*r to*r steal*r and*r kill*r and*r destroy;*r I*r have*r come*r that*r they*r may*r have*r life,*r and*r have*r it*r to*r the*r full.*r
“I*rp am*r the*r good*r shepherd.*r The*r good*r shepherd*r lays*r down*r his*r life*r for*r the*r sheep.*r

The*r hired*r hand*r is*r not*r the*r shepherd*r and*r does*r not*r own*r the*r sheep.*r So*r when*r he*r sees*r the*r wolf*r coming,*r he*r abandons*r the*r sheep*r and*r runs*r away.*r Then*r the*r wolf*r attacks*r the*r flock*r and*r scatters*r it.*r
The*r man*r runs*r away*r because*r he*r is*r a*r hired*r hand*r and*r cares*r nothing*r for*r the*r sheep.*r
“I*rp am*r the*r good*r shepherd;*r I*r know*r my*r sheep*r and*r my*r sheep*r know*r me—*r
just*r as*r the*r Father*r knows*r me*r and*r I*r know*r the*r Father—and*r I*r lay*r down*r my*r life*r for*r the*r sheep.*r

I*r have*r other*r sheep*r that*r are*r not*r of*r this*r sheep*r pen.*r I*r must*r bring*r them*r also.*r They*r too*r will*r listen*r to*r my*r voice,*r and*r there*r shall*r be*r one*r flock*r and*r one*r shepherd.*r
The*r reason*r my*r Father*r loves*r me*r is*r that*r I*r lay*r down*r my*r life—only*r to*r take*r it*r up*r again.*r

No*r one*r takes*r it*r from*r me,*r but*r I*r lay*r it*r down*r of*r my*r own*r accord.*r I*r have*r authority*r to*r lay*r it*r down*r and*r authority*r to*r take*r it*r up*r again.*r This*r command*r I*r received*r from*r my*r Father.”*r
The*p Jews who heard these words were again divided.
Many of them said, “He is demon-possessed and raving mad. Why listen to him?”
But*p others said, “These are not the sayings of a man possessed by a demon. Can a demon open the eyes of the blind?”
Further Conflict Over Jesus’ Claims
Then*p came the Festival of Dedication at Jerusalem. It was winter,
and Jesus was in the temple courts walking in Solomon’s Colonnade.
The Jews who were there gathered around him, saying, “How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly.”
Jesus*p answered, “I*r did*r tell*r you,*r but*r you*r do*r not*r believe.*r The*r works*r I*r do*r in*r my*r Father’s*r name*r testify*r about*r me,*r
but*r you*r do*r not*r believe*r because*r you*r are*r not*r my*r sheep.*r
My*r sheep*r listen*r to*r my*r voice;*r I*r know*r them,*r and*r they*r follow*r me.*r
I*r give*r them*r eternal*r life,*r and*r they*r shall*r never*r perish;*r no*r one*r will*r snatch*r them*r out*r of*r my*r hand.*r
My*r Father,*r who*r has*r given*r them*r to*r me,*r is*r greater*r than*r all;*r no*r one*r can*r snatch*r them*r out*r of*r my*r Father’s*r hand.*r
I*r and*r the*r Father*r are*r one.”*r
Again*p his Jewish opponents picked up stones to stone him,
but Jesus said to them, “I*r have*r shown*r you*r many*r good*r works*r from*r the*r Father.*r For*r which*r of*r these*r do*r you*r stone*r me?”*r
“We*p are not stoning you for any good work,” they replied, “but for blasphemy, because you, a mere man, claim to be God.”
Jesus*p answered them, “Is*r it*r not*r written*r in*r your*r Law,*r ‘I*r have*r said*r you*r are*r “gods” ’?*r
If*r he*r called*r them*r ‘gods,’*r to*r whom*r the*r word*r of*r God*r came—and*r Scripture*r cannot*r be*r set*r aside—*r

what*r about*r the*r one*r whom*r the*r Father*r set*r apart*r as*r his*r very*r own*r and*r sent*r into*r the*r world?*r Why*r then*r do*r you*r accuse*r me*r of*r blasphemy*r because*r I*r said,*r ‘I*r am*r God’s*r Son’?*r
Do*r not*r believe*r me*r unless*r I*r do*r the*r works*r of*r my*r Father.*r

But*r if*r I*r do*r them,*r even*r though*r you*r do*r not*r believe*r me,*r believe*r the*r works,*r that*r you*r may*r know*r and*r understand*r that*r the*r Father*r is*r in*r me,*r and*r I*r in*r the*r Father.”*r
Again they tried to seize him, but he escaped their grasp.
Then*p Jesus went back across the Jordan to the place where John had been baptizing in the early days. There he stayed,
and many people came to him. They said, “Though John never performed a sign, all that John said about this man was true.”
And in that place many believed in Jesus.
